docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. JOSEPH KELLER His Motto: 'Let's Do It!' On that last Sunday, Joseph Keller, bona fide grown-up -- father, husband, homeowner in Park Ridge, N.J., and department head at the Marriott World Trade Center Hotel -- had what would be a final fling with his daredevil teenage self. He and two buddies from high school got together and dusted off their old bicycle freestyling stunts. Mr. Keller, 31, who had competed in the extreme sport, still had the chops to pull off a funky chicken. (Don't ask.) ''If you were looking for someone to egg you on,'' said his friend Prentice Chang, ''Joe was like: 'Let's do it!' A lot of people followed his direction.''

headline.main: A Bicycle Daredevil, a Fearless Cook and a 79-Year-Old Mountaineer
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

docs.abstract: Brief profiles of some of victims of terrorist attack on World Trade Center; photos (M)

byline.original: These profiles were written by David W. Chen, Robin Finn, Jan Hoffman, Lynette Holloway, Kirk Johnson, Felicia R. Lee, Mireya Navarro, Maria Newman, Mirta Ojito, Somini Sengupta, Barbara Stewart and Daniel J. Wakin

docs.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, the trading firm that lost 700 employees in the World Trade Center attack, said the victims' families would receive health insurance for 10 years and a share of the partnership's profits for five years. The company said 25 percent of the money that would have been distributed to partners would be given to families of employees killed in the attacks over five years, or until they receive $100,000 each. Each will get a life insurance payment of double the victim's salary up to a maximum $100,000.

docs.lead_paragraph: As states start to assess the economic damage in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the outlook is dismal and getting worse. State after state, already reeling from the national economic slowdown, ordered a round of budget cuts in recent weeks, only to find that those cuts will not be enough. Many states, like Ohio, Georgia, Arizona and Kentucky, are now looking at even deeper cuts, hitting programs like mental health, Medicaid, prisons and education. Several states, like Connecticut and Kansas, say they are likely to go a step further: raising taxes or halting plans to cut taxes.

headline.main: First Round of Budget Cuts Aren't Enough, States Find

docs.abstract: States, already reeling from national economic slowdown, find economic damage from Sept 11 terrorist attacks is worsening dismal outlook; many have ordered round of budget cuts in recent weeks, only to find cuts will not be enough; weigh even deeper cuts; several are likely to raise taxes or drop planned cuts; face falling tax revenues and unforeseen expenses, including higher security spending (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The drug maker Pfizer Inc. joined I.B.M. and Microsoft yesterday to announce the official start of Amicore, an independent software and services company that aims to provide office automation products to doctors. The company named Jim Fitzsimmons as president and chief executive and said it had acquired a Connecticut health care software developer, the PenChart Corporation. Amicore enters an already competitive market. WebMD, one of the first companies to try to link doctors and insurance providers over the Web, has not been able to turn a profit, losing more than $800 million in the quarter ended June 30. WebMD and a competing alliance of insurance companies called MedUnite have encountered hurdles in their attempts to streamline the health care industry by linking various participants on the Net. Susan Stellin (NYT)

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Software: Venture To Make Products For Doctors

docs.lead_paragraph: Canadians may earn substantially less than Americans, but most of them still rate their quality of life higher, and their government-administered health service has long topped the list of reasons. That health service is now in trouble. How to fix it without ''Americanizing'' it is the problem. ''For Canadians, our publicly funded health care system is a key distinguishing characteristic of our country,'' a Canadian Senate committee report said in September. ''In fact, it has achieved iconic status. It is perceived to reflect Canadian values and these are seen to stand in sharp contrast to the values of our American neighbors.''
docs.abstract: Canada's government-administered health service, long praised by Canadians, is in trouble; how to fix it without 'Americanizing' it is problem; system leaves no one without essentially free access to most doctors and hospitals; federal and provincial governments share in paying bills, about $63 billion annually, from tax revenues and other income; soaring costs are now straining system; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The candidates in today's Democratic mayoral runoff ended their last full day of campaigning yesterday by dropping the combative tone of the past few days and focusing largely on shoring up their political bases. Both Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, and Mark Green, the city's public advocate, spent much of the day urging people to get out and vote at a time when the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack and the air raid on Afghanistan threaten to overshadow the campaigns.

headline.main: Green and Ferrer End Runoff Race With Softer Tone

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was a time -- it is celebrated and scorched in the movie ''Dinner Rush'' -- when New Yorkers stood in line at the restaurant of the moment and ate pumpkin risotto, and if the noise was deafening, who cared, because nobody listened anyway. Now no one is in the mood for a $100 bottle of wine.

headline.main: Mourning the Loss of the Prewar Superficial Values

docs.lead_paragraph: Elderly heart disease patients on Medicare who have no supplemental insurance are less likely to receive expensive prescription drugs that could extend their lives, according to a study released today. The report, from Brigham and Women's Hospital, Harvard Medical School and Harvard Pilgrim Health Care in Boston, comes as Congress struggles with ways to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly.

headline.main: Inequality in Availability of Heart Drugs Is Found

docs.abstract: Report finds that elderly heart patients on Medicare who have no supplemental insurance are less likely than others with similar conditions to receive expensive prescription drugs that can extend lives; chief author Dr Alex Federman urges Congress to consider creating drug benefit that targets lower income patients with Medicare (S)
docs.snippet: Elderly heart disease patients on Medicare who have no supplemental insurance are less likely to receive expensive prescription drugs that could extend their lives, according to a study released today.    The report, from Brigham and Women's...

docs.lead_paragraph: The port of Tacoma, Wash., was expecting a slack fourth quarter even before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. With slowing trade between North America and Asia, container traffic through the port was 11.7 percent lower in August than a year earlier, and Douglas V. Ljungren, the port's business planning manager, was forecasting an 8 percent decline in the final three months of the year. Now, Mr. Ljungren has revised the forecast to an 11 percent decline and is also projecting no growth in traffic through 2002. Even that is probably optimistic, he says.
docs.abstract: Container shipping industry throughout world is in deepening slump, result of sagging global economy, terrorist attacks in US and war on terrorism; companies whose vessels ply shipping lane between west coast of North America and Asia, world's busiest, have been hit particularly hard by economic slowdown as well as steady stream of big new container vessels joining route; freight rates have dropped sharply and sailing schedules are being trimmed, even as war on terrorism pushes up insurance rates; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a week of meetings, the Senate remained bogged down over the scope and cost of a bill to federalize the jobs of baggage screeners at major airports. The Senate began the day by voting 97 to 0 to proceed with the bipartisan bill, but leaders on both sides retreated behind closed doors to continue negotiating the legislation's most contentious measures.

headline.main: Senate Stalls On U.S. Role In Screening At Airports
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: SECURING THE SKIES

docs.abstract: Senate remains bogged down over scope and cost of bill to federalize jobs of baggage screeners at major airports; White House wants federal government to hire, train and supervise baggage screeners, without necessarily creating new federal work force; Republican sponsors of measure seek more flexibility over federalizing employees (M)
